docs.lead_paragraph: We've officially entered that part of the year when people feel the need to rank everything. And that includes really long magazine articles. So those of us at the One-Page Magazine (you know, that brand-spanking- new, extremely cool, funny first page of The Times Magazine) decided to inaugurate our own list of the year's best. We're calling it really, really short reads.
docs.abstract: Please submit your favorite really, really short reads by Dec. 29, or mark them with the Twitter handle @reallyreallyshortreads. We'll announce the winner before the year is up.
docs.snippet: Please submit your favorite really, really short reads by Dec. 29, or mark them with the Twitter handle @reallyreallyshortreads. We'll announce the winner before the year is up.

docs.lead_paragraph: Walmart and Supervalu have removed Enfamil, a popular brand of infant formula, from thousands of stores after a Missouri infant who consumed the product died.

headline.seo: Walmart Removes Enfamil Formula After Boy Dies
headline.main: Stores Remove Formula After Boy Dies
headline.print_headline: Stores Remove Formula After Boy Dies

docs.abstract: Walmart and Supervalu remove certain packages of infant formula Enfamil from thousands of their stores after Missouri infant who had consumed the product dies from a rare bacterial infection; action is unusual because there had been no official determination that formula had caused death, and neither the manufacturer nor federal officials had sought a recall.
docs.snippet: Walmart and Supervalu have removed Enfamil, a popular brand of infant formula, from thousands of stores after a Missouri infant who consumed the product died.

headline.main: Cauliflower and Red Onion Tacos With Cotija Cheese

docs.snippet: This filling turns a typical Mexican condiment into the piquant star of the meal.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Unified School District broke new ground earlier this year when it started phasing out junk food and offering students healthful new fare. The decision by L.A. Unified, one of the largest districts in the nation, to swap out corn dogs and chocolate milk for quinoa salads and vegetarian curries was seen as a move that might inspire other districts across the country to do the same.

headline.main: Students Say No to Healthful School Fare

docs.abstract: The decision in Los Angeles to swap out corn dogs and chocolate milk for quinoa salads and vegetarian curries was seen as a move that might inspire other districts across the country to do the same, but students aren't biting.
docs.snippet: The decision in Los Angeles to swap out corn dogs and chocolate milk for quinoa salads and vegetarian curries was seen as a move that might inspire other districts across the country to do the same, but students aren't biting.

headline.main: A Medical School More Like Hogwarts

docs.abstract: At Vanderbilt Medical School, students take an active role planning activities like fun runs and cooking competitions -- as student colleges, modeled on Harry Potter, compete.
docs.snippet: At Vanderbilt Medical School, students take an active role planning activities like fun runs and cooking competitions -- as student colleges, modeled on Harry Potter, compete.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of women in at least a half-dozen countries received the implants that were made with substandard silicone and that have been rupturing at unusually high rates.

headline.main: Health Fears Over Suspect French Breast Implants Spread Abroad
headline.print_headline: Health Fears Over Suspect French Breast Implants Spread Abroad

docs.abstract: Health officials around the globe are grappling with the intense anxiety of tens of thousands of women who received breast implants manufactured in France by Poly Implant Prothese using substandard silicone and now rupturing at unusually high rates; it remains unclear whether the type of silicone involved represents a health risk, and regulators will have to decide whether the known risks associated with removing the implants outweigh the uncertain risks and anxieties associated with leaving them intact.
docs.snippet: Tens of thousands of women in at least a half-dozen countries received the implants that were made with substandard silicone and that have been rupturing at unusually high rates.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Ravi Somaiya from London; Simon Romero from São Paulo, Brazil; Gardiner Harris from Washington; and Lis Moriconi from Rio de Janeiro.
byline.original: By MAÏA de la BAUME and DAVID JOLLY
